column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Causalstatements|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Ecosystem|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Focalpoint|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Locationofstudy|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Mainhypothesisandcorrespondingresults|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Method|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Reccomendationsandsuggestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Timeperiodofstudy|
#Text=Benthic communities influence coral seeding success at fine spatial scales.

#Text=Cathie A Page,�Christine Giuliano,�Carly J Randall\rFirst published: 24 June 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14212\rAuthor contributions: CAP, CG, CJR designed the experiment, collected the data, wrote the paper; CAP analyzed the data.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Gary Kendrick\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract.

#Text=The deployment of engineered substrates seeded with newly settled corals is a technique being developed to increase the numbers of juvenile corals on reefs with the goal of improving reef resilience in response to climate warming.

#Text=Using a hierarchical sampling design, we explored the spatial scales at which seeded coral (spat) survival and growth varied in situ and investigated the environmental drivers of seeded spat success in the southern inshore Great Barrier Reef.

#Text=After 10months, variation in spat survival and size was greatest at the smallest spatial scale (1_2m) (27 and 11% of variation, respectively), indicating the scale at which the main drivers of post_settlement survival and growth are occurring.
#Text=Crustose coralline algae (CCA) cover on seeding units prior to deployment was a significant driver of short_ and long_term spat survival (22% of variation).
#Text=Survival of�Acropora millepora�and�A. muricata�spat did not differ according to benthic community variation.

#Text=Increasing cover of branching�Acropora�corals was correlated with decreased survival and the size of�Montipora aequituberculata�spat, although CCA cover on plugs remained the most influential factor determining survival.

#Text=Interspecific variation in spat survival and size and higher survival and size in the side_facing orientation of the seeding units suggest natural variation in response to the seeding method, warranting further experiments to refine species selection and deployment methods prior to upscaling.
#Text=High within_site variation in seeded spat survival and size highlights the need for future studies of ecological factors driving post_settlement mortality at fine spatial scales.

#Text=Implications for Practice\r* High variation in seeded spat survival and size at fine spatial scales (1_2m) highlights the need for studies at this scale to resolve ecological drivers of post_settlement mortality in seeded corals.\r* Solutions to settle corals in the absence of live crustose coralline algae (CCA) should be prioritized given the reduced settlement and survival associated with high CCA cover.\r* Seeding densities may need to be adjusted to overcome the lower survival and size of some coral species in some environments.
#Text=Introduction.

#Text=Global coral populations are threatened by climate warming as marine heatwaves and resulting regional scale coral bleaching drive coral population declines (Gardner et al�2003; Hughes et al�2017; Sully et al�2019).

#Text=Coral declines have in turn reduced the supply of coral recruits to reefs (Hughes & Tanner�2000; Hughes et al�2019), reducing the capacity of populations to recover following disturbances (Hughes et al�2019).

#Text=In response, coral seeding restoration methods propose to boost the number of young corals on reefs, with the aim of increasing survival above background rates to accelerate recovery and adaptation to ocean warming (dela Cruz & Harrison�2017; Omori�2019; Randall et al�2020).

#Text=Coral seeding involves the delivery of larvae directly to the reef (Heyward et al�2002; dela Cruz & Harrison�2017) or the deployment of corals growing on seeding units to the reef (Chamberland et al�2017; Randall et al�2021).

#Text=Seeded coral survival may be increased above background rates through the addition of design features to seeded substrates, for example, crevices or protective features to limit grazing by fish, and/or the selective breeding or treatment of corals to increase their tolerance to heat (Chamberland et al�2017; Randall et al�2021).

#Text=Naturally high post_settlement mortality in young corals in situ is driven by a range of ecological factors or processes, the relative importance of which is likely to vary among reef regions, habitats, and coral species (Penin et al�2010; Trapon et al�2013; Miller�2014).

#Text=Environmental factors contributing to high post_settlement mortality include poor substrate quality (Fabricius et al�2017), high sedimentation (Moeller et al�2017; Doropoulos et al�2022), corallivory or accidental grazing by fishes (Penin et al�2010; Trapon et al�2013), and competition with conspecifics (Baird & Hughes�2000; Cameron & Harrison�2020) and other benthic organisms, including turfing and macroalgae (Box & Mumby�2007; Arnold et al�2010; Suzuki et al�2018).
#Text=The co_occurrence of many of these factors and processes in situ ensures that their contribution to post_settlement mortality remains difficult to disentangle.

#Text=Yet this knowledge is critical to ensure the efficacy of coral seeding deployments and also more broadly for the management of these factors to improve reef resilience (Randall et al�2020; Doropoulos et al�2022).

#Text=Hierarchical experimental designs allow identification of the spatial scale at which environmental factors or processes are operating and have previously successfully identified the spatial scales at which natural coral settlement varies (Dunstan & Johnson�1998; Hughes et al�1999; O'Leary & Potts�2011; Hern�ndez_Fern�ndez et al�2019).
#Text=Hierarchical designs provide a novel means to test the spatial scale of mortality drivers in corals deployed to the reef on seeding units.
#Text=Subsequent studies can then focus on the most appropriate scale to describe the nuance in these processes (Underwood & Chapman�1996; Hughes et al�1999; O'Leary & Potts�2011).

#Text=In situ benthic communities undoubtably influence post_settlement coral survival (Birrell et al�2008; Penin et al�2010) and are likely to play an important role in determining the success of coral seeding deployments (Randall et al�2023).

#Text=Fouling communities that colonize seeding substrates play an important role in the induction of coral settlement and post_settlement survival throughout early ontogeny (Doropoulos et al�2015,�2022).

#Text=Crustose coralline algae (CCA) are important inducers of coral larval settlement (Heyward & Negri�1999; Abdul Wahab et al�2023; Randall et al�2024) and are widely used to induce settlement of coral larvae to substrates for experiments and seeding deployments (Abdul Wahab et al�2023; Page et al�2023; Randall et al�2023).

#Text=However, CCA can also inhibit settlement and out_compete spat (Golbuu & Richmond�2007; Jorissen et al�2020; Ramsby et al�2024), resulting in suboptimal settlement or mortality reducing the efficacy of coral seeding deployments.

#Text=Positive and negative interactions between CCA and coral settlement and survival are dependent on the CCA and coral species involved, as well as environmental conditions (Doropoulos et al�2012; Jorissen et al�2020; Abdul Wahab et al�2023; Ramsby et al�2024).
#Text=Therefore, quantifying the role of CCA in coral mortality during seeding unit transport and after deployment is important to maximize the efficiency of future coral seeding efforts.

#Text=Here, we compared the performance (survival and growth) of seeded spat of three common coral species (Acropora muricata,�A. millepora, and�Montipora aequituberculata) in two deployment orientations (side_ and down_facing) in engineered experimental seeding units after a 10_month deployment to their natal inshore reefs of the southern Great Barrier Reef (GBR) (Keppel Islands).

#Text=We used a hierarchical experimental design to identify the spatial scales at which performance was most variable and examined variation in benthic communities adjacent to and on the seeding unit to identify potential drivers of seeded coral survival and growth.
#Text=Finally, we investigated the impact of seeding unit transport and pre_deployment benthic composition on survival.
#Text=Methods.
#Text=Coral Spawning, Larval Culturing, and Settlement.

#Text=In November 2020, replicate partial or whole colonies of�Acropora millepora,�A. muricata, and�Montipora aequituberculata�were collected from shallow reefs (4_6m below the lowest astronomical tide) of the Keppel Islands, Woppaburra Sea Country.
#Text=These species were abundant and often dominated coral communities in this region.

#Text=Corals were transported to the Australian Institute of Marine Science's (AIMS) National Sea Simulator facility and maintained in outdoor aquaria under ambient lighting and with a temperature regime equivalent to the natal reef 10_year average (23.7_25.0 degrees C, natal reef temperature regime [NRTR] as determined from an in situ weather station; AIMS�2009).
#Text=Trays of 20_mm diameter aragonite plugs were also held in these aquaria for 6weeks to develop a biofilm and recruit CCA.
#Text=Collection of coral gametes and larval culturing followed methods described in Heyward and Negri (1999) and are briefly described below.
#Text=Following the visible setting of gamete bundles, colonies were isolated in individual tanks.
#Text=After spawning, gamete bundles were collected from each colony, separated, washed, and all gametes per species combined to allow cross_fertilization for approximately 1hour.
#Text=Embryos were rinsed twice with filtered sea water (FSW, 0.45m) and transferred to 70 or 500L larval rearing tanks.
#Text=Larvae were maintained at NRTR and provided gentle aeration after 36_48hours.
#Text=Spawning occurred on 9 November 2020 for�A. millepora�and�A. muricata�and on 12 November 2020 for�M. aequituberculata.
#Text=Numbers of colonies contributing to cultures and the dates of coral spawning and settlement are summarized in Table�S1.

#Text=Conditioned aragonite plugs were transferred to clean, unconditioned trays and placed into 50L FSW flow_through tanks (26.4 degrees C) for settlement of larvae (8_10days after spawning, Table�S1).
#Text=Larvae were added to the tanks and allowed approximately 48hours to settle before a preliminary assessment.
#Text=If necessary, additional larvae were added to reach the desired settlement density (five or more spat per plug).
#Text=After approximately 5days, trays of settled corals (hereafter spat) were transferred to indoor aquaria for holding (80_120 photosynthetically available radiation [PAR], 26.4 degrees C).

#Text=Seeding Unit Assembly, Census, and Transport\rOn the 30th and 31st December 2020, one plug of each coral species was haphazardly loaded into each of the side and down_facing positions of 300 seeding units (Figs.�1A�&�S1).

#Text=Seeding units were designed to allow the deployment of spat of multiple coral species in two orientations to the same area of reef, so spat on each unit was exposed to the same environmental conditions, particularly adjacent benthic communities (Figs.�1A�&�S1).

#Text=Units were comprised of a central 21mm thick triangular piece of Illumina ceramic, designed to hold three side_facing and three down_facing plugs, with two polyvinyl chloride disks and a central nylon bolt and nut to secure the plugs.
#Text=The corners of the triangular ceramic unit provided partial protection of the plug from grazing by fish (Whitman et al�2024).
#Text=A detailed description of the seeding unit design and composition is provided in Figure�S1.

#Text=Each plug was imaged in situ (T0; Nikon D810), and the following data were collected from each plug photograph: (1) total number of discrete spat and (2) percent cover of CCA visually estimated into one of four categories (0_24%, 25_49%, 50_74%, and 75_100%).

#Text=Seeding units were maintained in indoor aquaria for 49days after settlement (5 January 2021), then transported in FSW_filled plastic tanks via refrigerated truck (approximately 27.0 degrees C) to the research vessel.
#Text=Seeding units were maintained onboard the vessel in plastic tanks with running unfiltered seawater at the ambient ocean temperature.
#Text=Water temperatures during transit were tracked via temperature loggers (HOBO MX2202) in two haphazardly chosen tanks (Fig�S2).

#Text=Figure 1\r\r(A) Seeding unit design, and (B) map indicating the location of the seeded coral deployments at three Keppel Island Reefs (Mazie Bay, Shelving Bay, and Halfway Island) in Woppaburra Sea Country (southern inshore Great Barrier Reef), and (C_E) seeding units in situ.

#Text=Pre_Deployment Mortality\rAfter 2days of holding on the vessel and prior to the first deployment (7 January 2020), 18 seeding units were haphazardly selected and placed in each of three replicate tanks.
#Text=At this point (2days), and again after 5 and 8days, plugs were examined under magnification and the number of live spat counted.
#Text=This included the full period that seeding units were held on the vessel to document early spat mortality during holding.
#Text=T0 photographs were used to track the fate of individual spat.
#Text=Spat that were touching were counted as one spatially discrete spat.
#Text=Seeding Unit Deployment\rWe used a hierarchical deployment design to measure spatial variation in seeded coral survival and growth (Fig�2).

#Text=Seeding units were deployed to three transects nested within three sites within each of three Keppel Island reefs (Halfway Island [Halfway], Mazie Bay of North Keppel Island [Mazie], and Shelving Bay reefs of Great Keppel Island [Shelving]) (Table�S2; Figs.�1B�&�2).
#Text=Reefs were chosen as being representative of back reef coral communities in the region.
#Text=Sites within reefs were separated by at least 100m and were chosen haphazardly to represent the range of coral communities within these environs.
#Text=At each of the nine sites, 10 seeding units were deployed along three haphazardly placed 10 m transects.
#Text=Transects followed depth contours and were separated by at least 3m.
#Text=Reinforcement bars (1.5_1.8m) were hammered into the reef and seeding units secured atop using plastic cable ties.
#Text=Seeding units were placed within approximately 1m of a central transect, but at least 1m away from any other seeding unit (Fig�2).
#Text=The bottom of the seeding unit sat as close as possible to, but without touching, the benthos (Figs.�1C_E�&�S1).
#Text=Units were deployed among the full range of major benthic groups (macroalgae and coral taxa) present on each transect.
#Text=Figure 2\r\r(A) Schematic showing the hierarchical deployment design, and (B) schematic showing the deployment of 10 seeding units along each approximately 10m transect.

#Text=PAR Measurements\rOn 1 August 2021 (between 10:00 and 12:35hours), instantaneous PAR was measured for 30 seeding units deployed at two Halfway Reef sites (Sites 1 and 2) using a miniature PAR sensor (Diving_LS, Heinz Walz, Germany) coupled to a submersible underwater fluorometer (Diving PAM, Walz, Germany).

#Text=To measure PAR, the sensor was held immediately in front of one haphazardly selected side_facing plug and immediately under one haphazardly selected down_facing plug per unit, in the small gap between the seeded plug and the benthos.

#Text=Post_Deployment Census\rIn April, August, and November 2021 (3, 7, and 10_months post_deployment, respectively), all units were surveyed and the dislodgement or burial of any devices was recorded.

#Text=In November 2021, all seeding units were retrieved, and the following data were collected from each plug: (1) presence/absence of at least one surviving spat; (2) visual evidence of any spat having fused together, and (3) the number of live, spatially discrete coral colonies present.
#Text=From the largest surviving colony per plug, the maximum linear length (maximum diameter), perpendicular length, and height of the skeleton were measured using digital calipers.

#Text=The benthos immediately surrounding each seeding unit was documented by photographing a 5050cm quadrat around each unit using a camera (Olympus Tough TG6 and housing) in April 2021 (approximately 4months after deployment).
#Text=For those few (n=4) seeding units missed in April, photos were retaken in November 2021, noting no major changes in benthic cover occurred in this period, based on qualitative assessments.
#Text=Benthic cover estimates were derived from point_count analyses of photoquadrats.
#Text=Using the ReefCloud platform (https://reefcloud.ai/), 20 points were overlaid in a grid over each photo.
#Text=Benthic organisms under each point were identified to the lowest possible taxonomic level, with most Scleractinia (stony corals) and macroalgae identified to genus (Table�S3).
#Text=Data Analysis\rAll statistical analyses were completed in R (R Core Team�2022) and all data were visualized using the ggplot2 package (Wickham�2016).

#Text=To investigate differences in settlement density among taxa, and their relation to initial cover of CCA on the settlement surface, we modeled the number of spat against coral species and CCA cover using a generalized linear mixed effect model (GLMM) with a negative binomial distribution, using the glmmTMB function from the glmmTMB package (Brooks et al�2017).

#Text=To investigate the survival of spat during transit, prior to deployment, we modeled the number of spat alive and dead (per plug), against time (0, 2, 5, and 8days), coral species, and their interaction (fixed factors) using a GLMM with a binomial distribution.
#Text=Seeding unit nested in the transport tank was included as a random effect.

#Text=To explore the role of CCA cover on the settlement surface in long_term survival, we modeled the number of spat alive or dead (per plug) at retrieval against the initial percent cover of CCA and coral species (fixed factors) using a GLMM as above.
#Text=Spatial and temporal trends in survival were investigated by modeling survival per plug (0=no survivors, 1=1 or more surviving spat) using a GLMM with a binomial distribution.
#Text=Coral species and deployment orientation were included as fixed factors.
#Text=Seeding unit nested in transect nested in site nested in reef was included as a random effect.
#Text=Initial cover of CCA was also included as a random effect given variation in settlement based on CCA cover (Fig�S3).
#Text=To account for variation in the initial number of spat per plug, the numbers of spat pre_deployment were included as offsets in the models.
#Text=Dislodged or buried devices were excluded from analyses of spat survival and size.
#Text=For all GLMMs, model diagnostics were checked using the DHARMa package (Hartig�2020) and assumptions validated.
#Text=For significant factors, pairwise comparisons were undertaken by calculating least squares means with a Tukey adjustment using the emmeans package (Lenth�2021).

#Text=Variance in spat survival explained by the various spatial scales was explored using the same GLMM, but with reef included as a random factor in which sites, transects, and seeding units were nested.
#Text=A�t�test was used to test for differences in PAR in the side_ and down_facing orientations using the t.test function in base R (R Core Team�2022).
#Text=Insufficient�A. muricata�spat survived 10months in the down_facing position to statistically compare size across orientations.
#Text=Therefore, the size (maximum linear length) of the largest spat per plug in the two orientations was compared by modeling data for�A. millepora�and�M. aequituberculata�only.
#Text=Spat size was modeled against coral species and orientation as fixed factors, using a GLMM with a Gaussian distribution.
#Text=Seeding unit nested in transect nested in site nested in reef was included as a random effect.
#Text=Cover of CCA on the plug at the time of deployment was included as a random effect.

#Text=Between_species and between_reef differences in spat size 10months after deployment were compared using data from side_facing plugs only for all three coral species by modeling the size of the largest spat per plug using a GLMM with a Gaussian distribution, as above.
#Text=Coral species and reef were included as fixed factors, while seeding unit nested in transect nested in site were included as a random effect.
#Text=CCA cover was also included as above.

#Text=Variance in size explained by the various spatial scales was explored using the above_described GLMM; however, reef was included as a random factor in which sites, transects, and seeding units were nested.

#Text=Yield (survival at the seeding_unit level) was compared among reefs by modeling the presence or absence of a surviving spat against the reef as a fixed factor using a GLMM with a binomial distribution.
#Text=Seeding unit nested in transect nested in site was included as a random effect.

#Text=To investigate how differences in the benthic communities surrounding each seeding unit relate to spat survival, we visualized the benthic communities using principal component analysis (PCA) with vector plots.
#Text=PCAs were generated using PCA from the FactoMineR package (Josse & Husson�2008) and visualized using fviz_pca_biplot from the factoextra package (Kassambara & Mundt�2020).

#Text=We then tested for differences in benthic community composition among reefs using a Bray_Curtis dissimilarity matrix of the cover of the main benthic groups using a permutational analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) with 999 permutations.
#Text=From the vegan package, the vegdist and adonis2 functions were used to calculate the dissimilarity matrix and the PERMANOVAs, respectively (Oksanen et al�2020).
#Text=Differences in dispersion among sites and devices were determined using the betadisper function from the vegan package (Oksanen et al�2020).
#Text=Only data from side_facing plugs were used in this analysis, given the low survival in the down_facing position.

#Text=For�M. aequituberculata�only, survival varied significantly with the benthic community; to describe the relationship between survival and the cover of specific benthic categories, a stepwise process was used.

#Text=First, benthic categories that contributed more than 10% to dimensions 1 and 2 of the PCA (described above) using fviz_contrib from the factoextra package (Kassambara & Mundt�2020) were identified.
#Text=Second, the relative influence of those benthic categories was then tested using the gbm function in the gbm package (Greenwell et al�2022).

#Text=Third, variables with a relative influence of 10% or greater (Table�S4) were modeled in a GLMM that excluded spatial factors (reef, site, transect, and seeding unit), to determine whether the cover of these benthic categories were significant predictors of�M. aequituberculata�survival.
#Text=Only data from side_facing plugs was used in this analysis, given low survival in the down_facing position.
#Text=Model diagnostics were checked and assumptions validated, as above.
#Text=Results.

#Text=Settlement averaged 6.4 spat per plug and ranged from 1 to 26 spat per plug;�Acropora millepora�settlement was highest (10.7+/-0.2 spat per plug), followed by�A. muricata�(4.3+/-0.1 spat per plug) and then�Montipora aequituberculata�(4.1+/-0.1 spat per plug) (Table�S5, Figure�S4, pairwise comparisons:�p<0.001).

#Text=Pre_Deployment Survival\rBy the last day of the seeding deployment (8days), onboard spat survival varied significantly among species, and was highest for�M. aequituberculata�(94.7+/-2.3%), intermediate for�A. millepora�(82.5+/-3.3%), and lowest for�A. muricata�(61.1+/-6.2%) (Table�S6; Fig�3A, pairwise comparisons:�p<0.002).
#Text=Declines in survival were significant for�A. muricata�and�A. milleporaonly (Table�S6; Fig�3A).

#Text=Spat survival was significantly lower (68.4+/-7%) on plugs with the highest percent cover of CCA (76_100%) compared to plugs with lower CCA cover (0_25% cover=92.2+/-2.8% survival; 25_50% cover=86.2+/-4.4% survival, and 51_75% cover=68.4+/-7% survival) (pairwise comparisons�p<0.002) (Table�S6; Fig�3B).
#Text=Spat were frequently observed being overgrown by CCA, particularly in the presence of high CCA cover (Fig�3C�&�3D).
#Text=Figure 3\r\rModeled proportional survival of spat against (A) time pre_deployment and (B) categorical percent cover of crustose coralline algae (CCA).
#Text=Colors represent coral species (red=Acropora millepora, green=A. muricata, and blue=Montipora aequituberculata).
#Text=(C) Example of high CCA cover and spat overgrowth by CCA, and (D) close_up of (C) showing spat overgrowth by CCA.
#Text=Diameter of plug in (C) is 20mm.
#Text=Lowercase letters indicate statistically significant differences among time periods pre_deployment.
#Text=Lowercase roman numerals indicate statistically significant differences among species.
#Text=Errors bars represent 0.95 CI around the modeled means.

#Text=Survival of Deployed Spat\rAverage survival was highest for�M.aequituberculata�(49.6+/-7.1%; pairwise comparisons:�p<0.001), intermediate for�A. millepora�(28.6+/-5.8%) and lowest for�A. muricata�(10.4+/-2.8; pairwise comparisons:�p<0.001) (Fig�4A).
#Text=For each species and within each deployment orientation, the probability of survival did not differ significantly among the three reefs (all pairwise comparisons:�p>0.2; Fig�4A).

#Text=On most plugs, survival was represented by one spat (A. muricata=94%,�A. millepora=80%, and�M. aequituberculata=78%), noting that this survivor may represent multiple genotypes that fused after deployment.

#Text=Yield (seeding_unit level survival) did not vary significantly among the three deployment reefs either (Shelving Bay: 90.8+/-3.1%, Halfway Island: 90.7+/-3.1%, and Mazie Bay=90.2+/-3.3%) (pairwise comparisons:�p>0.9; Table�S7).

#Text=After the 10_month deployment, seeding units were heavily fouled by sediment and benthic communities immediately adjacent to the units that had grown onto the units (predominately species of the brown algae�Lobophora) (Fig�5).

#Text=Figure 4\r\r(A) Proportional survival of three species of coral (Acropora millepora,�A. muricata, and�Montipora aequituberculata) after approximately 10months of deployment to Keppel Island reefs in both the side_ (orange) or down_facing (blue) orientations within seeding units.
#Text=(B) Photsynthetically available raditation (molm2s1) on the surface of side_ (orange) or down_facing (blue) plugs.
#Text=Asterisks indicate statistical significance between orientations.

#Text=(C) Size (maximum linear length [mm]) of�A. millepora�and�M. aequituberculata�spat after approximately 10months deployment at three reefs (Halfway, Mazie, and Shelving) in both the side_ (yellow) or down_facing (blue) orientation.
#Text=Asterisks indicate statistical significance between orientations.

#Text=(D) Size (maximum linear length [mm]) of�A. millepora,�A. muricata, and�M. aequituberculata�spat after approximately 10months deployment at three reefs (Halfway, Mazie, and Shelving) in the side_facing orientation only.
#Text=Lowercase letters indicate statistically significant differences among time periods pre_deployment.
#Text=Lowercase roman numerals indicate statistically significant differences among species.
#Text=Error bars represent 0.95 CI around the modeled means.
#Text=Figure 5\r\rExamples of side_ and down_facing surfaces of seeding units after their 10_month deployment at Halfway, Mazie, and Shelving reefs.
#Text=Examples of side_ and down_facing spat of�Acropora millepora,�A. muricata�(side_facing only spat shown), and�Montipora aequituberculata.
#Text=The probability of survival was over eight_fold higher in the side_facing (62.3%+/-6.3) than the down_facing orientation (7.2+/-1.9%) (Table�S7; Fig�4A).

#Text=PAR measured in the side_facing orientation was 70_fold higher (14.2+/-2.2molm2s1) than in the down_facing orientation (0.22+/-0.08molm2s1) (t=6.3497, degrees of freedom [df]=59.139,�p<0.001, Fig�4B).

#Text=Variation in survival after 10months on natal reefs was highest at the smallest spatial scale, the scale of the individual seeding unit (26% of variation) and decreased with increasing spatial scale (Table�S7).

#Text=The smallest percentage variation in survival (1%) was explained by among_reef differences, while differences among sites and transects explained 3% and 16.5% of the variation in survival, respectively (Table�S7).
#Text=Importantly, the cover of CCA per plug prior to deployment explained 22% of variation in spat survival (Table�S7).

#Text=Size of Deployed Spat\rAcropora millepora�and�M. aequituberculata�spat were two_ and four_fold larger, respectively, in the side_facing orientation compared to the down_facing orientation (Table�S8; Fig�5).

#Text=�Acropora millepora�spat averaged 17+/-0.9mm maximum diameter in the side_facing compared to 8+/-1.2mm in the down_facing orientation, while�M. aequituberculata�spat averaged 12.1+/-0.9mm in the side_ and 3.1+/-1.2mm in the down_facing orientation (pairwise comparisons�p<0.001; Fig�4C).
#Text=Insufficient numbers of�A. muricata�spat in the down_facing orientation survived the deployment to allow a between_orientation comparison of size (Fig�5).

#Text=In the side_facing position only,�A. millepora�spat was larger (17.4+/-0.6mm maximum diameter) than both�A. muricata�(13.4+/-0.9mm maximum diameter) and�M. aequituberculata(11.6+/-0.7 maximum diameter) (pairwise comparison:�p<0.001, Table�S8; Fig�4D).
#Text=Side_facing�A. muricata�and�M. aequituberculata�corals did not differ in size (pairwise comparison:�p=0.12, Fig�4D).

#Text=Side_facing corals deployed to Halfway Island and Mazie Bay reefs were similar in size after 10months (15.8+/-0.9mm and 14.3+/-0.9mm maximum diameter, respectively) (pairwise comparison:�p=0.53, Figs.�4D�&�6).

#Text=Side_facing corals at Shelving Bay reef were significantly smaller (12.2+/-0.9mm maximum diameter) than those deployed to Halfway Island (pairwise comparison:�p=0.02), but similar in size to those deployed to Mazie Bay (pairwise comparison:�p=0.53, Figs.�4D�&�6).

#Text=Figure 6\r\rPrincipal component analysis with benthic group vectors for benthic community composition among (A) reefs where all coral species are included and for seeding units on which corals survived (1) and died (0) for (B)�Montipora aequituberculata, (C)�Acropora millepora, and (D)�A. muricata.
#Text=Ellipses represent 95% CI.
#Text=Statistical significance (p>0.05) is indicated by an asterisk.
#Text=Variation in the size of side_facing spat 10months after deployment was highest at the smallest spatial scale, namely the scale of the individual seeding unit (11%).
#Text=A similarly small percentage of variation in size was explained at the site (4%) and reef scales (6%), while transects explained very little of the variation in spat size (<0.001%).
#Text=In contrast to survival, the cover of CCA accounted for very little variation in spat size (<1%) (Table�S8).

#Text=Influence of Reef Benthos on Size and Survival\rBenthic communities on the three deployment reefs varied significantly (df=2, SS=17.45,�r2=0.12,�F=50.83,�p=0.001), in part due to differences in the variation or dispersion of benthic communities at the three reefs (df=2, SS=5.75,�M2=2.87,�F=149.32, Perm=999,�p=0.001) (Fig�6A).

#Text=Benthic communities surrounding seeding units on which�M. aequituberculata�spat survived and died differed significantly (df=1, SS=0.90,�r2=0.018,�F=4.66,�p=0.003) (Fig�6B), although the communities were similarly dispersed (df=1, SS=0.02,�M2=0.02,�F=0.85, Perm=999,�p=0.38).

#Text=In contrast, the benthic communities surrounding the seeding units on which�A. millepora�and�A. muricata�spat survived and died did not differ significantly (A. millepora:�df=1, SS=0.131,�r2=0.002,�F=0.66,�p=0.59;�A. muricata:�df=1, SS=0.14,�r2=0.003,�F=0.711,�p=0.55; Fig�6C�&�6D).
#Text=Survival and size of�M. aequituberculata�decreased as the cover of branching�Acroporaincreased (Table�S9; Fig�7A�&�7C).
#Text=However, CCA cover prior to deployment was 70_fold more influential than branching�Acropora�cover in determining�M. aequituberculata�survival (Table�S9; Fig�7B).
#Text=Survival of�M. aequituberculata�spat 10months after deployment was lowest (52.3+/-7.8%) at the highest cover of CCA prior to deployment (76_100% cover; Fig�7B).

#Text=Figure 7\r\rRelationships between the probability of�Montipora aequituberculata�spat survival and (A) percent cover of branching�Acropora�spp., (B) percent cover of crustose coralline algae (CCA), and (C) the relationship between�M. aequituberculata�spat size (maximum linear length [mm]) and percent cover of branching�Acropora�spp.
#Text=Shaded areas and error bars represent 95% CI.
#Text=Discussion.

#Text=Knowledge of how seeding_unit design and deployment environment influence seeded coral performance is required to optimize this method prior to upscaling (Chamberland et al�2017; Doropoulos et al�2022; Randall et al�2023).

#Text=We used a coral seeding approach and a hierarchical experimental design to identify that: (1) high survival (up to 95%) could be achieved after 8days of on_vessel transport, (2) high CCA cover on seeding units prior to deployment was the most influential factor reducing both short (pre_deployment) and long_term (10months) survival, (3) side_facing spat were eight_fold more likely to survive and grew at least twice as large as down_facing spat, (4) survival and growth varied among the three species tested.

#Text=Importantly, we also identified that (5) variation in seeded coral survival and growth was highest at within_site spatial scales (between individual seeding units 1_2m apart), and (6) survival and size of�Montipora aequituberculata�spat declined with increasing cover of branching�Acropora�corals.
#Text=These results highlight the importance of applying scientific experiments to optimizing coral seeding methods.
#Text=Large_scale restoration using spat produced in land_based aquarium facilities will require a period of holding ahead of transport and deployment (Ramsby et al�2024).
#Text=Understanding spat survival during transport is critical to ensure sufficient seeding units are transported to the deployment reef to meet seeding targets.

#Text=Here, we demonstrated that high survival of seeded spat (up to 95%) can be achieved after 8days of on_vessel transport, longer than is required to reach the length and breadth of the GBR by vessel.

#Text=Yet, declines in survival of the two�Acropora�species associated with high CCA cover on the settlement surface, indicate that pre_deployment survival could be further increased via optimization of settlement and transport holding conditions (water quality and flow, light, feeding etc), particularly those that reduce competition between CCA and spat (Ramsby et al�2024).

#Text=We assumed that deployment to the reef would increase the competitiveness of seeded spat over CCA, given increased access to heterotrophic food sources on these turbid inshore reefs (Anthony�2006), combined with the potential exceedance of optimal light regimes of the CCA on the seeding units.
#Text=However, CCA cover prior to deployment remained an important determinant of long_term spat survival.

#Text=The impact of high CCA cover was greatest for�Acropora muricata�and lowest for�M. aequituberculata, and these species_level differences persisted until the conclusion of the 10_month deployment.
#Text=Therefore, deployment did not appear to enhance the competitiveness of spat against CCA or change trajectories in spat survival on seeding units with high cover of CCA.

#Text=Employing settlement methods that (1) minimize CCA cover and growth, (2) use less competitive CCA species, or (3) apply extracts or metabolites of CCA as settlement cues (Tebben et al�2015; Jorissen et al�2020; Quinlan et al�2023) offer three ways to reduce mortality of seeded spat by CCA inducers.
#Text=Lower survival and growth of down_facing spat were likely driven by lower light under the seeding units, despite down_facing seeded surfaces being close to the edge of the unit.

#Text=Higher mortality of spat on tile undersides furthest from the tile edge, where light intensity is lowest (Morse et al�1988; Cameron & Harrison�2020) and in shaded habitats (Baird & Hughes�2000), support this hypothesis.
#Text=The negative relationship between survival and growth of side_facing�M. aequituberculata�spat and the cover of branching�Acropora�spp.
#Text=(predominantly�A. muricata�and�A. intermedia) may also reflect the impact of shading by these fast_growing species that overtopped some seeding units after their 10_month deployment.

#Text=Low_profile encrusting morphologies, such as�M. aequituberculata, may be more sensitive to light limitation caused by shading from branching�Acropora�spp. or seeding design features, than the more erect morphologies tested here (A. millepora�and�A. muricata), whose survival was not related to branching�Acropora�cover.
#Text=These results may be reflective of the natural competitive dominance of�Acropora�in some habitats.
#Text=Allelopathy is another potential driver of reduced survival and growth of�M. aequituberculataspat at sites with high branching�Acropora�cover.

#Text=Species_specific responses to allelopathy are likely to vary (Sims et al�2021); hence, the negative relationship between high cover of branching�Acropora�spp. and the survival and growth of�M. aequituberculata�spat, but not the two�Acropora�species tested, does not negate the possible role of allelopathy.

#Text=The reduced efficacy of seeding some coral species at sites with high coral cover suggests that seeding densities of certain species may need to be increased to ensure survival targets are achievable.
#Text=The need to undertake coral seeding at sites with robust coral cover is counterintuitive.

#Text=However, the persistence of coral populations in warming oceans may require enhancement of the heat tolerance of existing coral populations via seeding from heat_adapted coral and symbiont broodstock (Van Oppen et al�2015).
#Text=Therefore, it is necessary to understand how seeding efficacy varies among coral species under these conditions.

#Text=Interspecific variation in survival and growth of seeded corals is not unexpected given variation in life_history strategies and post_settlement mortality and growth (Hughes & Tanner�2000; Penin et al�2010).

#Text=Low survival of seeded�A. muricata, a branching species that readily fragments and likely relies heavily on asexual reproduction, is consistent with this species' life_history strategy (Madin�2005; Darling et al�2012).
#Text=Branching coral species adapted to asexual fragmentation have been the focus of coral gardening restoration approaches (Bostr�m_Einarsson et al�2020).

#Text=Longer_term maintenance of diverse coral communities and populations in warming oceans will require methods that use sexually produced propagules (Anthony et al�2017; Randall et al�2020), and ideally those of heat_adapted broodstock inoculated with heat_evolved symbionts (Van Oppen et al�2015; Anthony et al�2017; Randall et al�2020).

#Text=Therefore, species_specific seeding densities or the development of seeding units with species_specific design features may be required to optimize the survival of different taxa (Randall et al�2021).

#Text=Quantifying variance in seeded spat survival and size attributable to different spatial scales provided important insights into the potential drivers of post_settlement survival and growth on inshore reefs and importantly, informed the scale at which we analyzed these relationships.

#Text=Variation in spat survival and size was greatest at the smallest spatial scale examined (<1m, 26% of variation in survival and 11% of variation in size), indicating that small_scale variation in ecological factors was more important than between_site (100sm) and between_reef (10skm) differences in factors like temperature and hydrodynamics (Hughes et al�1999; Hern�ndez_Fern�ndez et al�2019).
#Text=By contrast, only 1 and 4% of the variation in survival and size, respectively, was explained at the largest spatial scale.

#Text=Studies of natural coral settlement found similarly high variation at small spatial scales (1m), but also at very large spatial scales (ie 1_100s of km) (Dunstan & Johnson�1998; Hughes et al�1999; O'Leary & Potts�2011).
#Text=The lack of high variation at the reef_scale in this study may reflect similarities in the benthic communities and environmental conditions on the three sheltered reefs tested.

#Text=Further hierarchical coral seeding deployments, including deployments to multiple reef regions, reef zones (reef flanks, backs, and fronts) and a greater range of benthic communities, would aid in identifying the contribution of a wider range of environmental variables and benthic communities to seeded coral performance, particularly given variation in natural coral settlement and communities at these larger between region and within reef scales (Fisk & Harriott�1990; Dunstan & Johnson�1998; Hughes et al�1999; O'Leary & Potts�2011).

#Text=Nonetheless, the results of this study suggest that the measurement of small_scale differences in conditions alongside future coral seeding deployments would help identify the drivers of post_settlement mortality in seeded corals that can be managed through deployment method modifications.

#Text=We hypothesized that seeded spat survival and growth would be negatively correlated with the macroalgae cover on deployment reefs, given the pervasive negative impacts of macroalgae on corals (McCook et al�2001; Box & Mumby�2007; Smith et al�2022).
#Text=Indeed, Suzuki et al (2018) recorded reduced growth, but not survival, of seeded�Acropora�spat at a site with high macroalgae cover (mainly�Padina�and�Dictyota�spp.).

#Text=Interestingly, seeded spat survival and growth were not related to the cover of macroalgae in our study, including�Lobophora�spp., which dominated deployment reefs' macroalgal communities and is known to negatively impact coral settlement and post_settlement survival (Morrow et al�2012; Page et al�2023).

#Text=However, the cover of macroalgae generally, and�Lobophora�specifically, on reefs in this study was moderate (24_43% cover) compared to other inshore regions of the GBR (Ceccarelli et al�2020; Thompson et al�2024), and significant overlap in the benthic communities at the three deployment reefs possibly limited our ability to explore the influence of the full range of macroalgal cover on seeded spat performance.

#Text=Seeding across a wider range of benthic communities, including sites with both low and high macroalgae cover and where macroalgal communities are dominated by other genera (eg�Sargassum), may assist in identifying the role of macroalgae in seeded spat performance on inshore reefs.
#Text=Side_facing spat often fused with neighboring spat and grew until they filled the space between seeding unit protective features; spat occasionally grew onto the top of the seeding unit.
#Text=At this point, linear growth was restricted to the width of the gap between seeding unit protective features and the height of the device.
#Text=Therefore, in some cases, unit protective features constrained coral growth over the 10_month deployment.
#Text=Also, protective features appeared to promote the recruitment and colonization of seeding units by other organisms, including�Lobophora�spp., filamentous algae, sponges, and anemones.
#Text=These organisms often shaded spat or grew directly onto plug surfaces, thereby directly competing with spat.
#Text=Some spat survived this competition, but dead spat were observed underneath overtopping organisms or were directly overgrown.
#Text=Protective features may also shade spat, limiting growth.
#Text=Protective features tested here were designed to reduce the accessibility of spat to grazing fish and increased spat survival on a mid_shelf reef in the central GBR (Whitman et al�2024).

#Text=Grazing scars were observed on unprotected surfaces of seeding units, particularly down_facing surfaces; however, protective features may not be required in some reef environments, regions or habitats where fish grazing is not a strong driver of post_settlement coral mortality.
#Text=It is also possible that grazing protection is required in most environments, but other designs that minimize shading and overgrowth of spat would be more effective.
#Text=Here we identify potential areas of improvement in seeding_unit designs and aquaculture methods to further optimize seeding deployments, already in testing.
#Text=The success of previous coral seeding deployments, measured as yield (seeding_unit level survival), has been highly variable, ranging from 0 to 89% after 1year (reviewed in Randall et al�2023).

#Text=High yields reported here (approximately 90% across three reefs) likely reflect the installation of seeding units just above the substratum rather than directly on the substratum, as in previous studies (Chamberland et al�2017; Randall et al�2021,�2023).
#Text=We expect deployment of seeding units directly to the reef would result in reduced yield, although this requires testing.

#Text=Between_study differences in yield to date reflect differences in seeding unit designs, coral species, and deployment environments (Chamberland et al�2017; Suzuki et al�2018; Randall et al�2021,�2023).

#Text=Between_site variation in yield was attributed to variation in benthic communities in one mid_shelf GBR study (Randall et al�2023); however, further research is required to determine the relative influence of seeding unit design, species, and deployment environment on yield, but also to assess the longer_term success of coral seeding in different reef regions and settings, such as inshore versus offshore reefs.
#Text=Nonetheless, a yield of 90% in this study provides hope that coral seeding may prove an effective tool for increasing inshore coral population resilience.

#Text=While coral seeding may play a role in boosting the resilience of coral populations in the future, it must be undertaken in combination with reductions in other sources of reef degradation, including climate warming (Anthony et al�2017; Randall et al�2020).
